elements.content: In a series of nine group 12 metal complexes of 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(3-pyridinyl)­methanone (abbreviated as L), namely, [Cd­(L)2­Cl2] (1), [Cd­(L)2­(NO3)2]·3.5H2O (2), [Cd­(L)2­(H2O)2]­(NO3)2 (3), [Cd­(L)2­(H2O)2]­(ClO4)2·H2O (4), {[Cd­(L)­(H2O)2]­(ClO4)2·1.5H2O}∞ (5), {[Cd­(L)2­SO4­(H2O)]·2.8H2O}∞ (6), [Cd­(L)2­(CH3­CO2)2]∞ (7), [Zn­(L)2­(CH3­CO2)2]∞ (8), and [Hg­(L)2­(CH3­CO2)2]∞ (9), the semirigid multidentate ligand L exhibits flexible ligation modes I–IV in response to the cooperative effect of counteranions and solvent medium, leading to mononuclear (1–4), helical-chain (6), zigzag-chain (7), and 3D net (5) coordination motifs. The presence of the ancillary aqua ligand is essential for the crystallization of 3 and 5 by addition of deionized water to an organic mixed-solvent medium containing 2 and 4, respectively. The acetate complexes 7 (Cd2+), 8 (Zn2+), and 9 (Hg2+) are isostructural. Unconventional anion−π­(pyridine), CO···CO, O­(NO3 –/ClO4 –)···CO, and cohesive nitrate···nitrate interactions are manifested in supramolcular aggregations of the present series of crystalline complexes.

The presence of the ancillary aqua ligand is essential for the crystallization of 3 and 5 by addition of deionized water to an organic mixed-solvent medium containing 2 and 4, respectively. The acetate complexes 7 (Cd2+), 8 (Zn2+), and 9 (Hg2+) are isostructural. Unconventional anion-π(pyridine), CO⋅⋅⋅CO, O(NO3 -/ClO4 -)⋅⋅⋅CO, and cohesive nitrate⋅⋅⋅nitrate interactions are manifested in supramolcular aggregations of the present series of crystalline complexes.

elements.content: In a series of nine group 12 metal complexes of 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(3-pyridinyl)­methanone, this semirigid multidentate ligand exhibits flexible ligation modes in response to the cooperative effects of counteranions and solvent medium, resulting in mononuclear, helical-chain, zigzag-chain, and 3D net coordination motifs, which are assembled into diverse supramolecular architectures through several unusual noncovalent intermolecular interactions.
elements.clean_text: In a series of nine group 12 metal complexes of 2,6-pyridinediylbis(3-pyridinyl)methanone, this semirigid multidentate ligand exhibits flexible ligation modes in response to the cooperative effects of counteranions and solvent medium, resulting in mononuclear, helical-chain, zigzag-chain, and 3D net coordination motifs, which are assembled into diverse supramolecular architectures through several unusual noncovalent intermolecular interactions.

elements.content: Over the past decade, the coordination chemistry of di-2-pyridinyl­methanone (common name: di-2-pyridyl ketone, also abbreviated as DPK) and the oligo-pyridyl ketone 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(2-pyridinyl)­methanone has attracted wide attention because these ligands can exist in their neat, alcoholated hemiketal and hydrated gem-diol forms in either an uncharged or a deprotonated state in coordination to metal centers. In view of possible rotation about the C–C σ bonds and the availability of multiple bonding (N and O atom) sites, such ligands and their derivatives feature flexible ligation modes in the generation of diverse metal complexes with fascinating structures. Inspired by this consideration, some notable papers have addressed the coordination chemistry of positional isomers of DPK. In comparison, the coordination chemistry of analogous oligo-pyridyl ketone remains little explored, although several copper­(II) and silver­(I) complexes of 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(3-pyridinyl)­methanone and 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(4-pyridinyl)­methanone in their neat forms were recently reported by our group. In the metal complexes of these oligo-pyridyl ketones, the multiple carbonyl groups are found to engage in unusual noncovalent interactions to yield three-dimensional supramolecular frameworks: four distinct types of unconventional CO···π interactions and three principal types of CO(δ−)···C(δ+)O interactions are identified in the Cu­(II) complexes with 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(3-pyridinyl)­methanone and the Ag­(I) complexes with 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(4-pyridinyl)­methanone, respectively. For the 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(3-pyridinyl)­methanone ligand, rotational freedom about each outer C­(carbonyl)–C­(pyridyl) σ bond leads to variation in the coordination directions of the 3-pyridyl N sites to a metal ion (Scheme ).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past decade, the coordination chemistry of di-2-pyridinylmethanone (common name: di-2-pyridyl ketone, also abbreviated as DPK) and the oligo-pyridyl ketone 2,6-pyridinediylbis(2-pyridinyl)methanone has attracted wide attention because these ligands can exist in their neat, alcoholated hemiketal and hydrated gem-diol forms in either an uncharged or a deprotonated state in coordination to metal centers. In view of possible rotation about the C-C σ bonds and the availability of multiple bonding (N and O atom) sites, such ligands and their derivatives feature flexible ligation modes in the generation of diverse metal complexes with fascinating structures. Inspired by this consideration, some notable papers have addressed the coordination chemistry of positional isomers of DPK. In comparison, the coordination chemistry of analogous oligo-pyridyl ketone remains little explored, although several copper(II) and silver(I) complexes of 2,6-pyridinediylbis(3-pyridinyl)methanone and 2,6-pyridinediylbis(4-pyridinyl)methanone in their neat forms were recently reported by our group. In the metal complexes of these oligo-pyridyl ketones, the multiple carbonyl groups are found to engage in unusual noncovalent interactions to yield three-dimensional supramolecular frameworks: four distinct types of unconventional CO⋅⋅⋅π interactions and three principal types of CO(δ-)⋅⋅⋅C(δ+)O interactions are identified in the Cu(II) complexes with 2,6-pyridinediylbis(3-pyridinyl)methanone and the Ag(I) complexes with 2,6-pyridinediylbis(4-pyridinyl)methanone, respectively. For the 2,6-pyridinediylbis(3-pyridinyl)methanone ligand, rotational freedom about each outer C(carbonyl)-C(pyridyl) σ bond leads to variation in the coordination directions of the 3-pyridyl N sites to a metal ion (Scheme ).

elements.clean_text: 1  Ligation Modes of Ligand L in Complexes 1-9

elements.content: It is well-established that the reaction temperature, solvent system, pH value of the solution medium, selective combination of metal ion(s) with counteranion(s), and the presence of auxiliary neutral ligands all play a crucial role in the syntheses of desired coordination complexes. Herein, we report the role of anion and solvent in the generation of a series of group 12 metal complexes of 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(3-pyridinyl)­methanone (hereafter abbreviated as L, Scheme ), namely, [Cd­(L)2­Cl2] (1), [Cd­(L)2­(NO3)2]·3.5H2O (2), [Cd­(L)2­(H2O)2]­(NO3)2 (3), [Cd­(L)2­(H2O)2]­(ClO4)2·H2O (4), {[Cd­(L)­(H2O)2]­(ClO4)2·1.5H2O}∞ (5), {[Cd­(L)2­SO4­(H2O)]·2.8H2O}∞ (6), [Cd­(L)2­(CH3­CO2)2]∞ (7), [Zn­(L)2­(CH3­CO2)2]∞ (8), and [Hg­(L)2­(CH3­CO2)2]∞ (9). The supramolecular assemblies in these complexes are also discussed.

The supramolecular assemblies in these complexes are also discussed.

elements.content: All chemicals were obtained commercially from Aldrich and used without further purification. Elemental analysis of C, H, and N of each complex was performed by the MEDAC LTD Brunel Science Centre, United Kingdom. IR spectra were measured on a Nicolet Impact 420 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets. 1H NMR spectra were taken at 300 MHz with a Bruker-300 spectrometer using CDCl3 as solvent. 2,6-Pyridine­diyl­bis­(3-pyridinyl)­methanone (L) was prepared following the literature procedure. All complexes were, respectively, obtained by reaction of ligand L with the corresponding Cd­(II) salts (Cl–, NO3 –, ClO4 –, SO4 2–, and CH3CO2 –), or Zn­(II) and Hg­(II) acetates, in a 1:1 molar ratio except for 6 (2:1). Complexes 2, 4, and 7–9 were crystallized in a mixed solvent of acetonitrile and methanol, whereas 1, 3, 5, and 6 were obtained by adding deionized water to the organic solvent system. Complex 1 was obtained by reaction at heating condition, whereas all other reactions were performed at room temperature. Variation of the salt-to-ligand molar ratio generally led to the same product for complexes 1 and 7–9, whereas an oil-like residue of unknown composition was obtained for 2–6.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All chemicals were obtained commercially from Aldrich and used without further purification. Elemental analysis of C, H, and N of each complex was performed by the MEDAC LTD Brunel Science Centre, United Kingdom. IR spectra were measured on a Nicolet Impact 420 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets. 1H NMR spectra were taken at 300 MHz with a Bruker-300 spectrometer using CDCl3 as solvent. 2,6-Pyridinediylbis(3-pyridinyl)methanone (L) was prepared following the literature procedure. All complexes were, respectively, obtained by reaction of ligand L with the corresponding Cd(II) salts (Cl-, NO3 -, ClO4 -, SO4 2-, and CH3CO2 -), or Zn(II) and Hg(II) acetates, in a 1:1 molar ratio except for 6 (2:1). Complexes 2, 4, and 7-9 were crystallized in a mixed solvent of acetonitrile and methanol, whereas 1, 3, 5, and 6 were obtained by adding deionized water to the organic solvent system. Complex 1 was obtained by reaction at heating condition, whereas all other reactions were performed at room temperature. Variation of the salt-to-ligand molar ratio generally led to the same product for complexes 1 and 7-9, whereas an oil-like residue of unknown composition was obtained for 2-6.

elements.content: Solubility is a primary factor of consideration as a judicial choice of solvent can significantly enhance the reactivity of the solute. In the present context, a mixture of acetonitrile and methanol was chosen as a suitable solvent. Water was used as an additional solvent component in view of its capacity to function as an aqua ligand and engage in hydrogen-bonding interactions in the supramolecular assembly. Complex [Cd­(L)2­Cl2] (1) was obtained in mixed acetonitrile, methanol, and deionized water under heating condition; when the reaction was carried out without adding deionized water or at room temperature, only an indissoluble precipitate was obtained. Complexes [Cd­(L)2­(NO3)2]·3.5H2O (2) and [Cd­(L)2­(H2O)2]­(NO3)2 (3) serve as good examples of how the choice of solvent dictates the final product structure, and the same applies to complexes [Cd­(L)2­(H2O)2]­(ClO4)2·H2O (4) and {[Cd­(L)­(H2O)2]­(ClO4)2·1.5H2O} (5). Regarding these two pairs of complexes, complexes 2 and 4 crystallized in a mixed solution of acetonitrile and methanol, whereas 3 and 5 were obtained by introducing deionized water into the organic solvent system of 2 and 4, respectively. The aqua ligand of 2 and 4 may come from solvent used without purification or from atmospheric moisture. This phenomenon was also found for [Cu­(L)2­(NO3)2]·CH3­CN·H2O in a previous study. As an undesired unknown oil-like product was obtained in the reaction of L with 3CdSO4·8H2O in mixed acetonitrile and methanol, crystalline complex 6 was alternatively achieved by adding deionized water to the mixed solvent. Isostructural acetate complexes 7–9 were prepared in mixed acetonitrile and methanol, and the presence of water makes no difference in the product formation.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis Consideration and General Characterization

Solubility is a primary factor of consideration as a judicial choice of solvent can significantly enhance the reactivity of the solute. In the present context, a mixture of acetonitrile and methanol was chosen as a suitable solvent. Water was used as an additional solvent component in view of its capacity to function as an aqua ligand and engage in hydrogen-bonding interactions in the supramolecular assembly. Complex [Cd(L)2Cl2] (1) was obtained in mixed acetonitrile, methanol, and deionized water under heating condition; when the reaction was carried out without adding deionized water or at room temperature, only an indissoluble precipitate was obtained. Complexes [Cd(L)2(NO3)2]⋅3.5H2O (2) and [Cd(L)2(H2O)2](NO3)2 (3) serve as good examples of how the choice of solvent dictates the final product structure, and the same applies to complexes [Cd(L)2(H2O)2](ClO4)2⋅H2O (4) and {[Cd(L)(H2O)2](ClO4)2⋅1.5H2O} (5). Regarding these two pairs of complexes, complexes 2 and 4 crystallized in a mixed solution of acetonitrile and methanol, whereas 3 and 5 were obtained by introducing deionized water into the organic solvent system of 2 and 4, respectively. The aqua ligand of 2 and 4 may come from solvent used without purification or from atmospheric moisture. This phenomenon was also found for [Cu(L)2(NO3)2]⋅CH3CN⋅H2O in a previous study. As an undesired unknown oil-like product was obtained in the reaction of L with 3CdSO4⋅8H2O in mixed acetonitrile and methanol, crystalline complex 6 was alternatively achieved by adding deionized water to the mixed solvent. Isostructural acetate complexes 7-9 were prepared in mixed acetonitrile and methanol, and the presence of water makes no difference in the product formation.

elements.content: At room temperature, 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(3-pyridinyl)­methanone L (29 mg, 0.1 mmol) and CdCl2 (19 mg, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in a mixed solvent of 2 mL of acetonitrile and 2 mL of methanol together with 1 mL of deionized water. A yellow precipitate was obtained, which was redissolved under heating. After filtration, the clear solution was left to stand in air for about 5 days to yield colorless crystals of 1. Yield: 21.0 mg (55%). Calcd. (Found) for C34H22­N6O4­Cl2Cd: C, 53.60 (53.49); H, 2.91 (3.21); N, 11.03 (11.43) %. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of complexes 1, 3, 5, 6, and 9 were carried out on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer operating at 50 kV and 30 mA using Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), whereas those of the other complexes were performed on a Bruker SMART APEXII CCD diffractometer. The intensities were collected at 293 K, and data reduction was performed using the SMART and SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. All nine structures were solved by direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were subjected to anisotropic refinement. The positions of the hydrogen atoms of water molecules were obtained from Fourier-difference maps, while the remaining hydrogen atoms were introduced in the refinement at calculated positions. In complex 2, O1W and O3W are disordered at two positions with a ratio of 1:1, O2W with a ratio of 3:2, and O4W exhibits half site occupancy. One perchlorate O11 in 4 is disordered over two equal sites. O4W in 5 has half site occupancy. In complex 6, lattice water O1W is disordered over two positions with a ratio of 3:2, while O2W has a 0.8 site occupancy. All hydrogen atoms of the lattice water molecules in 2, O3W and O4W in 5, and O1W, O2W and O3W are not included in the structure refinement. The high residual peaks of complexes 1–9 range from 0.287 to 1.291 Å–3. The largest value of 1.291 Å–3 is found at 1.070 Å from the Hg atom in complex 9, while another one larger than 1 Å–3 is found at 0.947 Å from the perchlorate Cl atom in complex 4. The alert of isotropic non-H atoms in the main residue for 3 may be caused by the bent configuration of L because the largest residue peak is 0.682 Å–3, and no possible disordered position was found in 3. The high Ueq checkcif alert as compared to neighboring atoms for O5­(NO3 –) in 2 may be ascribed to the O­(NO3 –)···O­(nitrate) and O­(NO3 –)···π­(pyridine) interactions, which enhances the thermal vibrational parameter of nitrate O5. The crystal data and refinement parameters of complexes 1–9 are listed in Table . CCDC numbers 906619–906627 contain the supplementary crystal data for 1–9, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Powder patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance Powder X-ray diffractometer (CuKα, λ = 1.5418 Å) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA, with a graphite reflected beam monochromator and variable divergence slits. The experimental patterns match well with the simulated forms of the single-crystal X-ray data of those complexes (, Figure S1).

In mononuclear Cd­(L)2­Cl2 (1), the hexacoordinated, N4Cl2-octahedral Cd­(II) center has one symmetry (Figure a) with ligand L, adopting the κ2-N,N-chelating mode (mode III). Four 3-pyridyl N atoms from two L ligands constitute the equatorial sites of each octahedral Cd­(II) ion. The axial chloro groups of the N4Cl2-coordinated Cd­(II) center bridge the mononuclear units through C–H···Cl–M hydrogen bonding (C···Cl, 3.656(3)/3.570(3) Å; C–H···Cl, 125°/130°) with an R2 1(5) motif to form infinite chains along the c axis, which further interconnect through π···π interactions (centroid···centroid 3.818(4) Å) to generate a layer in the ac plane (Figure b).

Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structures

Structure of [Cd(L)2Cl2] (1)

In mononuclear Cd(L)2Cl2 (1), the hexacoordinated, N4Cl2-octahedral Cd(II) center has one symmetry (Figure a) with ligand L, adopting the κ2-N,N-chelating mode (mode III). Four 3-pyridyl N atoms from two L ligands constitute the equatorial sites of each octahedral Cd(II) ion. The axial chloro groups of the N4Cl2-coordinated Cd(II) center bridge the mononuclear units through C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl-M hydrogen bonding (C⋅⋅⋅Cl, 3.656(3)/3.570(3) Å; C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl, 125°/130°) with an R2 1(5) motif to form infinite chains along the c axis, which further interconnect through π⋅⋅⋅π interactions (centroid⋅⋅⋅centroid 3.818(4) Å) to generate a layer in the ac plane (Figure b).

elements.content: In the crystal structure of complex 2, there are two independent Cd­(II) atoms (designated Cd1 and Cd2) that are located at inversion centers. Each Cd­(II) has N4O2-coordination geometry with four 3-pyridyl N (from a pair of κ2-N,N-chelating L) at the equatorial sites and two nitrate O atoms at the axial sites, forming a molecular unit similar to that in complex 1 (Figure ). The observed Cd–N (2.357(7)–2.402(6) Å) and Cd–O (2.335(7)–2.418(7) Å) bond lengths vary within narrow ranges. Interestingly, the two independent trans-Cd­(L)2­(NO3)2 molecules interconnect through CO(δ−)···C(δ+)O, O­(NO3 –)···C(δ+)O, unconventional anion­(NO3 –)···π­(pyridine) contact, and cohesive nitrate···nitrate interactions. Regarding the nitrate···nitrate affinity, as shown in Figure , the N7- and N8-containing nitrates from separate mononuclear units exhibit a N···N separation of 3.424(3) Å, with a shortest O­(nitrate)···O­(nitrate) of 2.949(2) Å that is close to the sum of van der Waals radii (2.80 Å) of two O atoms in contact. The torsion angle N7–O7···O8–N8 is 23.6(2)°, and the dihedral angle between the NO3 – planes equals 20.4(2)°. Such short nitrate···nitrate contact may be ascribed to interacting between the π orbital of nitrates, which has not yet been documented in the literature. A Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) search was conducted at an O···O distance range of 2.8–3.2 Å and a N···N separation range of 3.0–3.4 Å, and no hit was found to meet these criteria. Further scrutiny reveals that the N7-containing nitrate also approaches close to one pyridyl ring of the opposite Cd2 unit with an O7­(NO3 –)···centroid distance of 3.302(2) Å, an O7­(NO3 –)···C24a­(closest ring atom) contact of 3.182(3) Å, and a N7···centroid distance of 3.472(2) Å (Figure ). Such O­(NO3 –)···π­(pyridine) contact is analogous to a lone-pair aromatic interaction that is of current interest, and the present O­(NO3 –)···centroid distance of 3.302(2) Å compares well to the mean anion­(NO3 –)···centroid­(pyridine) distance of 3.302 Å surveyed by Reedijk et al. through CSD search. Meanwhile, the N8-containing nitrate of the Cd2 unit exhibits an O­(NO3 –)···CO contact at an O10···C6b distance of 3.268(3) Å to link to the Cd1 unit (Figure ). The local dipoles of the nucleophile and carbonyl groups may mainly contribute to such close O­(NO3 –)(δ−)···C(δ+)O affinity. Furthermore, one CO on the Cd2 unit also points toward one CO group of the Cd1 unit with an O4a···C12b distance of 3.071(2) Å and a CO(δ−)···C(δ+)O torsion angle of 157.2(3)°, indicating a sheared parallel CO···CO interaction motif, being one of the three types of carbonyl···carbonyl interactions documented in the literature. Apparently, it is the multiple cooperative interactions that drive the nitrates close to each other.

A Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) search was conducted at an O⋅⋅⋅O distance range of 2.8-3.2 Å and a N⋅⋅⋅N separation range of 3.0-3.4 Å, and no hit was found to meet these criteria. elements.content: Taking the intermolecularly connected octahedral Cd1 and Cd2 units as a dimer (Figure a), other sets of intermolecular CO···CO contacts together with π···π interactions (centroid···centroid 3.546(3) Å) set in to link them together, furnishing a three-dimensional supramolecular framework with lattice water molecules embedded within it (Figure b). The O(δ−)···C(δ+) distances of the CO(δ−)···C(δ+)O contacts vary from 3.031(1) to 3.236(2) Å, while the CO(δ−)···C(δ+)O torsion angles lie within the 131.8(2)–130.9(2)° range, indicating also a sheared parallel motif.

elements.content: Mononuclear complex [Cd­(L)2­(H2O)2]­(NO3)2 (3) can be viewed as a result of replacing each chloride ligand on the trans-octahedral N4Cl2Cd­(II) unit of 1 by an aqua ligand (Cd1–O1W 2.318(3) Å), which functions as a peripheral linkage to assemble the mononuclear units into a 3-D supramolecular architecture through O–H­(H2O)···O­(NO3 –) interactions (Table ). Each mononuclear unit bridges four nitrates to form a hydrogen-bonded layer almost parallel to the bc plane (Figure a). Along the a direction, such layers are further connected by CO(δ−)···C(δ+)O interactions with an O2···C6b distance of 3.114(4) Å and a CO···CO torsion angle of 114.0(4)°, yielding a sheared parallel motif similar to that in 2 to engender a 3-D supramolecular framework (Figure b). Apparently, the cooperative CO···CO and H-bonding interactions drive the mononuclear units to pack in a dense mode, and thus, no lattice water molecule is embedded within the framework as found in 2, although deionized water was added to the solvent medium in the synthesis of 3.

Structure of [Cd(L)2(H2O)2](NO3)2 (3)

Mononuclear complex [Cd(L)2(H2O)2](NO3)2 (3) can be viewed as a result of replacing each chloride ligand on the trans-octahedral N4Cl2Cd(II) unit of 1 by an aqua ligand (Cd1-O1W 2.318(3) Å), which functions as a peripheral linkage to assemble the mononuclear units into a 3-D supramolecular architecture through O-H(H2O)⋅⋅⋅O(NO3 -) interactions (Table ). Each mononuclear unit bridges four nitrates to form a hydrogen-bonded layer almost parallel to the bc plane (Figure a). Along the a direction, such layers are further connected by CO(δ-)⋅⋅⋅C(δ+)O interactions with an O2⋅⋅⋅C6b distance of 3.114(4) Å and a CO⋅⋅⋅CO torsion angle of 114.0(4)°, yielding a sheared parallel motif similar to that in 2 to engender a 3-D supramolecular framework (Figure b). Apparently, the cooperative CO⋅⋅⋅CO and H-bonding interactions drive the mononuclear units to pack in a dense mode, and thus, no lattice water molecule is embedded within the framework as found in 2, although deionized water was added to the solvent medium in the synthesis of 3.

elements.content: Complex 4 (Figure ) contains mononuclear units similar to that in complex 3. The asymmetric unit contains two independent Cd­(II) centers (Cd1, Cd2) with Cd–N bond lengths varying in the 2.322(4)–2.382(3) Å range. Because of their weak coordination ability, perchlorates are positioned between Cd1 and Cd2 units through cooperative O–H­(H2O)···O­(ClO4 –) (Table ), anion­(ClO4 –)···π, and O­(ClO4 –)···CO interactions. As for anion­(ClO4 –)···π, an O10 atom points to one N2-containing pyridyl ring with an O···centroid distance of 3.463(5) Å (Figure ). Regarding the local dipoles of the O­(ClO4 –)···C(δ+)O contact, the O9···C29b distance equals 3.055(4) Å (Figure ), being shorter than the sum (3.12 Å) of van der Waals radii of O and C atoms. Along the b axis, the Cd2 units are connected by the CO(δ−)···C(δ+)O interaction (Figure a) with an O4···C23a separation of 3.264(6) Å and a CO···CO torsion angle of 120.8(7)°, indicating a sheared parallel motif comparable to that in 2 and 3. The other kind of CO(δ−)···C(δ+)O interaction found between the Cd1 units has an O2a···C12 distance of 3.197(5) Å and a CO···CO torsion angle of 180°, exhibiting a typical antiparallel motif as documented in the literature, which combines with a π···π interaction to connect the Cd1 units together in the ab plane (Figure b).

Structure of [Cd(L)2(H2O)2](ClO4)2⋅H2O (4)

Complex 4 (Figure ) contains mononuclear units similar to that in complex 3. The asymmetric unit contains two independent Cd(II) centers (Cd1, Cd2) with Cd-N bond lengths varying in the 2.322(4)-2.382(3) Å range. Because of their weak coordination ability, perchlorates are positioned between Cd1 and Cd2 units through cooperative O-H(H2O)⋅⋅⋅O(ClO4 -) (Table ), anion(ClO4 -)⋅⋅⋅π, and O(ClO4 -)⋅⋅⋅CO interactions. As for anion(ClO4 -)⋅⋅⋅π, an O10 atom points to one N2-containing pyridyl ring with an O⋅⋅⋅centroid distance of 3.463(5) Å (Figure ). Regarding the local dipoles of the O(ClO4 -)⋅⋅⋅C(δ+)O contact, the O9⋅⋅⋅C29b distance equals 3.055(4) Å (Figure ), being shorter than the sum (3.12 Å) of van der Waals radii of O and C atoms. Along the b axis, the Cd2 units are connected by the CO(δ-)⋅⋅⋅C(δ+)O interaction (Figure a) with an O4⋅⋅⋅C23a separation of 3.264(6) Å and a CO⋅⋅⋅CO torsion angle of 120.8(7)°, indicating a sheared parallel motif comparable to that in 2 and 3. The other kind of CO(δ-)⋅⋅⋅C(δ+)O interaction found between the Cd1 units has an O2a⋅⋅⋅C12 distance of 3.197(5) Å and a CO⋅⋅⋅CO torsion angle of 180°, exhibiting a typical antiparallel motif as documented in the literature, which combines with a π⋅⋅⋅π interaction to connect the Cd1 units together in the ab plane (Figure b).

elements.content: A 3D network structure markedly different from that of 4 was formed in complex 5, as deionized water was introduced into the solvent system. Figure a shows that each Cd­(II) atom in 5 exhibits seven-coordinate N3O4-geometry, a distorted pentagonal geometry surrounded by three L and two aqua ligands (O1W and O2W). As shown in Figure b, the conformation of L differs from that found in 1–4, taking an η3-ligation mode (mode IV, Scheme ) with all donor sites (three pyridyl N and two carbonyl O atoms) involved in coordination bonding. Both carbonyl O atoms and the N atom of the central pyridyl ring of L chelate the Cd­(II) atom, which is also coordinated by two N atoms (N1 and N3b) belonging to peripheral pyridyl rings of adjacent L ligands. Through assembly with the seven-coordinated Cd­(II) atoms and η3-bridging ligand L (mode IV), a 3D channel-type coordination framework is generated with the perchlorate ions and lattice water molecules (O3W and O4W) accommodated within it (Figure ), wherein O3W and O4W anchor to aqua ligands O1W and O2W through H-bonding (D···A 2.735(5) Å, 3.018(5) Å, D–H···A 134°, 125°).

elements.content: Further scrutiny revealed that the anion­(ClO4 –)···π­(pyridine), O­(ClO4 –)···C(δ+)O, and O–H­(H2O)···O­(ClO4 –) interactions combine to fix the perchlorate ion within the coordination framework of 5. For the Cl1-containing perchlorate, the O6 atom is in contact with the central pyridyl ring of one L with an O···centroid distance of 3.503(2) Å. Furthermore, O5­(ClO4 –)···C12O1 and O1Wb–H1W···O3­(ClO4 –) interactions are also found for the Cl1-containing perchlorate (O5···C12 3.054(2) Å; O1Wb···O3 3.132(3) Å, O1 Wb–H1W···O3 144°) (Figure b). For the Cl2-containing perchlorate, the anion links two independent L ligands around Cd1 through O9 and O7 atoms involving O­(ClO4 –)···CO and/or anion­(ClO4 –)···π interactions, and anchors to aqua O2Wa via O10 involving H-bonding interaction (O2Wa···O10 2.878(2) Å, O2Wa–H2W···O10 121°. a, x – 1/2, −y + 3/2, −z + 1). For O9, as shown in Figure b, the O···centroid­(pyridine) and O···C­(carbonyl) distances are 3.555(3) and 3.160(3) Å, respectively. For O7, the value of the O···centroid­(pyridine) distance is 3.548(2) Å. In comparison, the O­(ClO4 –)···centroid­(pyridine) distances around 3.5 Å of the anion­(ClO4 –)···π­(pyridine) interactions in 4 and 5 are comparable to the mean O­(ClO4 –)···centroid­(pyridine) distance of 3.3 Å surveyed by Reedijk et al. through CSD search. As to the local dipole O­(ClO4 –)···C(δ+)O interaction, the O···C distances vary from 3.054(4) to 3.160(3) Å, being comparable to 3.055(4) Å found in complex 4 and 3.268(3) Å for O­(NO3 –)···CO in 2. These distances are shorter than or similar to the sum (3.12 Å) of van der Waals radii of the O and C atoms. Driven by these cooperative forces, the perchlorate ions with weak bonding ability are located far away from Cd­(II) to be embedded within the metal–organic network (Figure ).

elements.content: Apparently, in 5, the deionized water added to the solvent not only affects the ligation mode of L but also changes the trans-octahedral N4O2Cd­(II)-coordination center in 4 to an N3O4Cd­(II)-coordination center, leading to a 3-D coordination network differing markedly from that of mononuclear complex 4. For the other pair of complexes 2 and 3, the ligand ligation mode (III) of L and the N4O2-coordination Cd­(II) in 3 are analogous to those in complex 2, and the water molecule introduced into the solvent system of 3 just functions as a competitive auxiliary aqua ligand to displace the nitrate.

For the other pair of complexes 2 and 3, the ligand ligation mode (III) of L and the N4O2-coordination Cd(II) in 3 are analogous to those in complex 2, and the water molecule introduced into the solvent system of 3 just functions as a competitive auxiliary aqua ligand to displace the nitrate.

elements.content: The sulfate ion (SO4 2–) is commonly used as a versatile bridged coligand in constructing a number of metal coordination complexes. In complex {[Cd­(L)2­SO4­(H2O)]·2.8H2O}∞ (6), a helical-chain structure is generated by a μ2-bridging sulfate (Figure ). Interestingly, ligand L exhibits two ligation modes, a new coordination mode I with only one 3-pyridyl N atom bonding to Cd­(II), and the κ2-N,N -chelating mode III as found in 1–4 (Scheme ). The Cd­(II) center exhibiting octahedral N3O3-coordination geometry is surrounded by two L ligands, one aqua ligand (O4W), and two sulfate O atoms (O8 and O7a, Figure ). Herein, the μ2-bridging sulfate links one Cd­(II) with O8 at an equatorial site and symmetry-related Cd­(II) with O7 at an axial site (Figure a). The octahedral Cd­(II) atoms and the μ2-bridging sulfates are thus alternatively arranged along the b axis, generating a 21 helical chain (Figure b).

Structure of {[Cd(L)2SO4(H2O)]⋅2.8H2O}∞ (6)

The sulfate ion (SO4 2-) is commonly used as a versatile bridged coligand in constructing a number of metal coordination complexes. In complex {[Cd(L)2SO4(H2O)]⋅2.8H2O}∞ (6), a helical-chain structure is generated by a μ2-bridging sulfate (Figure ). Interestingly, ligand L exhibits two ligation modes, a new coordination mode I with only one 3-pyridyl N atom bonding to Cd(II), and the κ2-N,N -chelating mode III as found in 1-4 (Scheme ). The Cd(II) center exhibiting octahedral N3O3-coordination geometry is surrounded by two L ligands, one aqua ligand (O4W), and two sulfate O atoms (O8 and O7a, Figure ). Herein, the μ2-bridging sulfate links one Cd(II) with O8 at an equatorial site and symmetry-related Cd(II) with O7 at an axial site (Figure a). The octahedral Cd(II) atoms and the μ2-bridging sulfates are thus alternatively arranged along the b axis, generating a 21 helical chain (Figure b).

elements.content: The 21 helical chains of opposite chirality are alternatively arranged to form a racemate that is stabilized by π···π (centroid···centroid distances lie within the 3.640(6)–3.765(5) Å range) and CO(δ−)···C(δ+)O interactions. For the latter interaction, the O···C distances vary from 2.954(6) to 3.123(6) Å and the CO···CO torsion angles span from 146.3° to 148.9°, indicating a sheared parallel motif comparable to that in 2–4 [O···C: 3.031(1)–3.264(6) Å, CO···CO torsion angle: 114.0(4)–157.2(3)°]. In this instance, the O···C distances of CO(δ−)···C(δ+)O interactions vary within a narrow range (2.954(6)–3.264(6) Å) that are in good agreement with that (2.975–3.432 Å) surveyed in a series of silver­(I) complexes with 2,6-pyridinediylbis­(4-pyridinyl)­methanone. These results are also consistent with theoretical calculation (2.92–3.32 Å), but longer than 2.796 Å in the organometallic complex (η5-C5H5)­W­(CO)3(η5-N-maleimidato) owing to the presence of coordinated carbonyl groups (ion-polarization) in the latter.

elements.content: In complex [Cd­(L)­(CH3­CO2)2]∞ (7), ligand L takes a μ2-bridging mode (II) (Figure a), a new ligation mode different from those of 1–6. The Cd­(II) atom and L atoms lie on adjacent 2-fold axes with the octahedral N2O4-coordinated Cd­(II) ion surrounded by two κ2-O,O-chelating acetates and two symmetry-related L ligands (Figure a). Each L bridges two Cd­(II) through the terminal 3-pyridyl N atoms to generate an infinite zigzag chain. The polymeric chains are assembled into a 2-D hydrogen-bonded layer in the bc plane (Figure b) through C–H­(pyridyl)···O­(CH3CO2 –) hydrogen bonding (D···A 3.428(3) Å, D–H···A 162°), and are further stacked through C–H···O­(carbonyl) (D···A 3.386(2) Å, D–H···A 147°) and C–H­(acetate)···π interactions to generate a 3-D supramolecular framework (C···centroid 3.661(2) Å, C–H···centroid 98°). As complexes [M­(L)­(CH3­CO2)2]∞ [M = Cd (7), Zn (8), Hg (9)] constitute an isostructural series, the structures of 8 and 9 will not be discussed here.

Structures of [M(L)(CH3CO2)2]∞ [M = Cd (7), Zn (8), Hg (9)]

In complex [Cd(L)(CH3CO2)2]∞ (7), ligand L takes a μ2-bridging mode (II) (Figure a), a new ligation mode different from those of 1-6. The Cd(II) atom and L atoms lie on adjacent 2-fold axes with the octahedral N2O4-coordinated Cd(II) ion surrounded by two κ2-O,O-chelating acetates and two symmetry-related L ligands (Figure a). Each L bridges two Cd(II) through the terminal 3-pyridyl N atoms to generate an infinite zigzag chain. The polymeric chains are assembled into a 2-D hydrogen-bonded layer in the bc plane (Figure b) through C-H(pyridyl)⋅⋅⋅O(CH3CO2 -) hydrogen bonding (D⋅⋅⋅A 3.428(3) Å, D-H⋅⋅⋅A 162°), and are further stacked through C-H⋅⋅⋅O(carbonyl) (D⋅⋅⋅A 3.386(2) Å, D-H⋅⋅⋅A 147°) and C-H(acetate)⋅⋅⋅π interactions to generate a 3-D supramolecular framework (C⋅⋅⋅centroid 3.661(2) Å, C-H⋅⋅⋅centroid 98°). As complexes [M(L)(CH3CO2)2]∞ [M = Cd (7), Zn (8), Hg (9)] constitute an isostructural series, the structures of 8 and 9 will not be discussed here.

elements.content: The counteranions Cl–, NO3 –, ClO4 –, CH3CO2 –, and SO42– exhibit different coordination abilities, electron densities, van der Waals volumes, steric bulk, and molecular geometries, which have been rationally utilized to regulate the desired supramolecular architecture of numerous metal complexes. The Cd­(II) complexes 1 (Cl–), 2 (NO3 –), and 3 (NO3 –) are mononuclear species with a metal-to-L ratio of 1:2 to form the same kind of trans-octahedral N4X2-coordination center (X = Cl, O). The NO3 – ion has a larger van der Waals volume than Cl–, and hence, the N4O2-center generated by nitrate is more crowded with respect to a N4Cl2-center. Therefore, it is understandable that the aqua ligand successfully replaces NO3 – to form a new N4O2-coordination center as deionized water is introduced into the solvent medium of 2 to yield 3. In contrast, the N4Cl2-surrounded Cd­(II) center of 1 is stable enough to resist possible replacement by the aqua ligand. As for perchlorate, its larger size and weaker coordination ability versus nitrate precludes its binding to the Cd­(II) center, leading to N4O2-coordination in 4 and N3O4-coordination in 5 through the lack and presence of added deionized water to the solvent medium, respectively. Notably, the very different ligation mode (IV) of L and the seven-coordinate N3O4-geometry in 5 with respect to those of 1–3 (a common κ2-N,N-chelating mode III and a similar N4X2-geometry) indicate that formation of the Cd­(II) perchlorate complex is more sensitive to the presence of water in the solvent medium. In comparison, SO4 2– has a similar tetrahedral geometry as ClO4 –, but the higher negative charge makes it a strong bridging coligand in many metal complexes. Herein, SO4 2– functions as a μ2-bridging coligand to form an infinite helical structure in complex 6. Furthermore, the large van der Waals volume of SO4 2– makes the Cd­(II) center more crowded, and thus, one of the two surrounding L ligands adopts coordination mode I rather the common κ2-N,N-chelating mode III in complexes 1–4. The acetate ion, in view of its peculiar geometry and different van der Waals volume and coordination ability with respect to those of the aforementioned anions, plays a distinctly different role to regulate the assembly of the Cd­(II) complex 7, in which ligand L takes a μ2-bridging mode II different from those in complexes 1–6, thereby leading to an infinite zigzag chain. The experimental finding that the same product 7 was obtained even if the solvent and/or the molar ratio of the starting materials were changed (see the ) implies that the zigzag-chain structure with μ2-bridging L is a preferential final product. Furthermore, successful syntheses of isostructural acetate complexes with other group 12 metal ions [M­(L)­(CH3­CO2)2]∞ [Zn (8), Hg (9)] also elucidate this point of view. However, attempts to obtain other Zn­(II) and Hg­(II) complexes with different counteranions were unsuccessful.

The counteranions Cl-, NO3 -, ClO4 -, CH3CO2 -, and SO42- exhibit different coordination abilities, electron densities, van der Waals volumes, steric bulk, and molecular geometries, which have been rationally utilized to regulate the desired supramolecular architecture of numerous metal complexes. The NO3 - ion has a larger van der Waals volume than Cl-, and hence, the N4O2-center generated by nitrate is more crowded with respect to a N4Cl2-center. Therefore, it is understandable that the aqua ligand successfully replaces NO3 - to form a new N4O2-coordination center as deionized water is introduced into the solvent medium of 2 to yield 3. In contrast, the N4Cl2-surrounded Cd(II) center of 1 is stable enough to resist possible replacement by the aqua ligand. As for perchlorate, its larger size and weaker coordination ability versus nitrate precludes its binding to the Cd(II) center, leading to N4O2-coordination in 4 and N3O4-coordination in 5 through the lack and presence of added deionized water to the solvent medium, respectively. In comparison, SO4 2- has a similar tetrahedral geometry as ClO4 -, but the higher negative charge makes it a strong bridging coligand in many metal complexes. Herein, SO4 2- functions as a μ2-bridging coligand to form an infinite helical structure in complex 6. Furthermore, the large van der Waals volume of SO4 2- makes the Cd(II) center more crowded, and thus, one of the two surrounding L ligands adopts coordination mode I rather the common κ2-N,N-chelating mode III in complexes 1-4. The acetate ion, in view of its peculiar geometry and different van der Waals volume and coordination ability with respect to those of the aforementioned anions, plays a distinctly different role to regulate the assembly of the Cd(II) complex 7, in which ligand L takes a μ2-bridging mode II different from those in complexes 1-6, thereby leading to an infinite zigzag chain. The experimental finding that the same product 7 was obtained even if the solvent and/or the molar ratio of the starting materials were changed (see the ) implies that the zigzag-chain structure with μ2-bridging L is a preferential final product. elements.content: The ligand L can be viewed as a central pyridyl ring bearing two pendant 3-pyridyl rings through a pair of bridging carbonyl groups. As observed in many metal complexes of the pyridyl ketone family, each pyridyl ring is rotatable about the C­(carbonyl)–C­(pyridyl) σ bond upon subtle tuning by variation of the coordination geometry of the metal center, solvent, and/or counteranions. Four flexible ligation modes of L (Scheme ) were found in complexes 1–9. In general, 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(3-pyridinyl)­methanone takes chelating mode III in 1–4 and 6, which may be ascribed to its natural strain-free molecular conformation with two pendant 3-pyridyl rings favorably positioned for metal chelation. This ligation mode also exists in its copper­(II) complexes: [Cu­(L)2­(BF4)2] and [Cu­(L)2­(NO3)2]·CH3CN·H2O.
elements.clean_text:
Ligation Behavior of 2,6-Pyridinediylbis(3-pyridinyl)methanone

The ligand L can be viewed as a central pyridyl ring bearing two pendant 3-pyridyl rings through a pair of bridging carbonyl groups. As observed in many metal complexes of the pyridyl ketone family, each pyridyl ring is rotatable about the C(carbonyl)-C(pyridyl) σ bond upon subtle tuning by variation of the coordination geometry of the metal center, solvent, and/or counteranions. Four flexible ligation modes of L (Scheme ) were found in complexes 1-9. In general, 2,6-pyridinediylbis(3-pyridinyl)methanone takes chelating mode III in 1-4 and 6, which may be ascribed to its natural strain-free molecular conformation with two pendant 3-pyridyl rings favorably positioned for metal chelation. This ligation mode also exists in its copper(II) complexes: [Cu(L)2(BF4)2] and [Cu(L)2(NO3)2]⋅CH3CN⋅H2O.

elements.content: Furthermore, L exhibits its neat ketone form in 1–9 with different metals and anions, which is in agreement with the ligation behavior of the positional isomers of di-2-pyridinyl­methanone (di-2-pyridyl ketone or DPK), such as 2-pyridinyl-3-pyridinyl­methanone, 2-pyridinyl-4-pyridinyl­methanone, di-3-pyridinyl­methanone, and 3-pyridinyl-4-pyridinyl­methanone. To date, a metal-assisted hydration and alcoholate reaction has been observed only for DPK and the oligo-pyridyl ketone 2,6-pyridinediyl­bis­(2-pyridinyl)­methanone. To our knowledge, the literature contains just a few examples of the gem-diol form (4-C5H4N)2­C­(OH)2 of di-4-pyridinyl­methanone (4-DPK) in its Cu­(II) and Pt­(II) complexes, and the tertiary carbinol form (4-C5H4N)2­C­(OH)­(NH­C3H7) in its Co­(II) complex. The experimental evidence gathered thus far indicates that suitable positioning of the N atoms on the heterocyclic rings is essential for manifestation of metal-assisted hydration or alcoholate reaction at the carbonyl carbon of a dipyridyl ketone, although whether metal coordination occurs after or prior to the hydrated/alcoholated reaction remains an unsettled issue.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, L exhibits its neat ketone form in 1-9 with different metals and anions, which is in agreement with the ligation behavior of the positional isomers of di-2-pyridinylmethanone (di-2-pyridyl ketone or DPK), such as 2-pyridinyl-3-pyridinylmethanone, 2-pyridinyl-4-pyridinylmethanone, di-3-pyridinylmethanone, and 3-pyridinyl-4-pyridinylmethanone. To date, a metal-assisted hydration and alcoholate reaction has been observed only for DPK and the oligo-pyridyl ketone 2,6-pyridinediylbis(2-pyridinyl)methanone. To our knowledge, the literature contains just a few examples of the gem-diol form (4-C5H4N)2C(OH)2 of di-4-pyridinylmethanone (4-DPK) in its Cu(II) and Pt(II) complexes, and the tertiary carbinol form (4-C5H4N)2C(OH)(NHC3H7) in its Co(II) complex. The experimental evidence gathered thus far indicates that suitable positioning of the N atoms on the heterocyclic rings is essential for manifestation of metal-assisted hydration or alcoholate reaction at the carbonyl carbon of a dipyridyl ketone, although whether metal coordination occurs after or prior to the hydrated/alcoholated reaction remains an unsettled issue.

elements.content: Semirigid, multidentate 2,6-pyridine­diyl­bis­(3-pyridinyl)­methanone (L) exhibits flexible ligation modes in response to cooperative effects of counteranions and solvent medium. Four ligation modes (I–IV) of L were observed in a series of Cd­(II) (1–7), Zn­(II) (8), and Hg­(II) (9) complexes with various counteranions, leading to mononuclear (1–4), 3D net (5), helical (6), and zigzag-chain (7–9) coordination motifs. Complexes [Cd­(L)2­(NO3)2]·3.5H2O (2) and [Cd­(L)2­(H2O)2]­(NO3)2 (3) provide good examples of how the solvent system can be used to fine-tune the final product structure, and the same applies to [Cd­(L)2­(H2O)2]­(ClO4)2·H2O (4) and {[Cd­(L)­(H2O)2]­(ClO4)2·1.5H2O} (5). Acetate complexes 7 (Cd2+), 8 (Zn2+), and 9 (Hg2+) constitute an isomorphous series with a zigzag coordination chain motif. All nine group 12 complexes of L were characterized by X-ray crystallography, FT-IR spectroscopy, and elemental analyses. Unconventional anion−π­(pyridine), CO···CO, O­(NO3 –/ClO4 –)···CO, and cohesive nitrate···nitrate interactions are manifested in supramolecular aggregations of those complexes. The present study shows that the ligand behavior of oligo-pyridyl ketones in other transition-metal complexes is worthy of further investigation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Semirigid, multidentate 2,6-pyridinediylbis(3-pyridinyl)methanone (L) exhibits flexible ligation modes in response to cooperative effects of counteranions and solvent medium. Four ligation modes (I-IV) of L were observed in a series of Cd(II) (1-7), Zn(II) (8), and Hg(II) (9) complexes with various counteranions, leading to mononuclear (1-4), 3D net (5), helical (6), and zigzag-chain (7-9) coordination motifs. Complexes [Cd(L)2(NO3)2]⋅3.5H2O (2) and [Cd(L)2(H2O)2](NO3)2 (3) provide good examples of how the solvent system can be used to fine-tune the final product structure, and the same applies to [Cd(L)2(H2O)2](ClO4)2⋅H2O (4) and {[Cd(L)(H2O)2](ClO4)2⋅1.5H2O} (5). Acetate complexes 7 (Cd2+), 8 (Zn2+), and 9 (Hg2+) constitute an isomorphous series with a zigzag coordination chain motif. All nine group 12 complexes of L were characterized by X-ray crystallography, FT-IR spectroscopy, and elemental analyses. Unconventional anion-π(pyridine), CO⋅⋅⋅CO, O(NO3 -/ClO4 -)⋅⋅⋅CO, and cohesive nitrate⋅⋅⋅nitrate interactions are manifested in supramolecular aggregations of those complexes. The present study shows that the ligand behavior of oligo-pyridyl ketones in other transition-metal complexes is worthy of further investigation.

A yellow precipitate was obtained, which was redissolved under heating. After filtration, the clear solution was left to stand in air for about 5 days to yield colorless crystals of 1. The cloudy solution was filtered, and the resulting colorless filtrate was left to stand in air for 1 week to deposit brown block-like crystals of 2. Yield: 19.6 mg (45%). Calcd. IR (KBr) ν/cm-1: 3400(w), 3099(w), 1688(vs), 1610(s), 1548(w), 1448(s), 1390(vs), 1306(s), 1202(w), 1041(w), 1002(w), 976(w), 924(m), 872(w), 769(w), 691(m), 652(w).

Synthesis of [Cd(L)2(H2O)2](ClO4)2⋅H2O (4)

L (29 mg, 0.1 mmol) and Cd(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (42 mg, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in a mixed solvent of 2 mL of acetonitrile and 3 mL of methanol with stirring at room temperature. The colorless solution was filtered to remove the insoluble solid, and the filtrate was left to slowly evaporate in air. Colorless block-like crystals of 4 were deposited after about 2 weeks. Yield: 30.7 mg (65%). Calcd. (Found) for C34H28N6O15Cl2Cd: C, 43.26 (43.55); H, 2.99 (2.88); N, 8.90 (8.98) %. IR (KBr) ν/cm-1: 3412(w), 3066(w), 1682(vs), 1598(s), 1420(w), 1328(vs), 1210(w), 1166(vs), 1093(w), 1001 (w), 933(w), 859(s), 746(s), 700(s), 647(w).

Synthesis of {[Cd(L)(H2O)2](ClO4)2⋅1.5H2O}∞ (5)

Complex 5 was synthesized from L (29 mg, 0.1 mmol) and Cd(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (42 mg, 0.1 mmol) following the procedure for 4, except that a mixed solvent of acetonitrile (2 mL), methanol (3 mL), and deionized water (1 mL) was used to obtain prismatic colorless crystals of 5. Yield: 30.5 mg (46%). Calcd. (Found) for C17H18N3O13.5Cl2Cd: C, 30.73 (31.05); H, 2.71 (2.58); N, 6.33 (6.38) %. IR (KBr) ν/cm-1: 3422(w), 3079(w), 1682(vs), 1591(s), 1416(w), 1332(vs), 1209(w), 1164(vs), 1092(w), 995(w), 930(w), 859(s), 743(s), 704(s), 646(w).

Synthesis of {[Cd(L)2SO4(H2O)⋅2.8H2O}∞ (6)

L (58 mg, 0.2 mmol) and 3CdSO4⋅8H2O (76 mg, 0.1 mmol) were introduced to a mixed solvent of 2 mL of acetonitrile and 2 mL of methanol with stirring at room temperature for 3 h. A 1 mL portion of deionized water was then added, and the cloudy solution changed to clear. After filtration, the colorless filtrate was left to stand in air for about 2 weeks. Yellow block-like crystals of 6 were deposited in 60% yield (51.5 mg). Calcd. (Found) for C34H29.6N6O11.8SCd: C, 47.69 (47.56); H, 3.46 (3.56); N, 9.83 (9.67) %. Synthesis of [Cd(L)(CH3CO2)2]∞ (7)

L (29 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added to a solution of Cd(CH3CO2)2⋅2H2O (27 mg, 0.1 mmol) in a mixed solvent of 2 mL of acetonitrile and 3 mL of acetone with stirring. After 3 h, the resulting clear solution was filtered and allowed to stand for about 3 weeks to give colorless crystals of 7. Yield: 26.5 mg (51%). Calcd. Synthesis of [Zn(L)(CH3CO2)2]∞ (8)

Complex 8 was synthesized employing the procedure for 7 with L (29 mg, 0.1 mmol) and Zn(CH3CO2)2⋅(H2O)2 (22 mg, 0.1 mmol). Yellow crystals were deposited after 2 weeks. Yield: 26 mg (55%). Calcd. Yellow crystals of complex 9 were obtained by repeating the procedure for 7-8 with L (29 mg, 0.1 mmol) and Hg(CH3CO2)2 (32 mg, 0.1 mmol). Yield: 30 mg (49%). Calcd.
